verses.text: Beloved, this is now the second letter I am writing to you. In both of them I am stirring up your sincere mind by way of reminder,
verses.comment: Peter emphasizes the continuity of his message and his concern for the believers to remain steadfast in true doctrine, showing apostolic authority and care.

verses.text: that you should remember the words spoken beforehand by the holy prophets and the commandment of the Lord and Savior, through your apostles.
verses.comment: Peter unites the Old Testament prophets with Christ's command given through the apostles, indicating the need for unity and apostolic succession in doctrinal teaching (Eph 2:20).

verses.text: Know this first: In the last days mockers will come with their mocking, following after their own desires,
verses.comment: This warning echoes other apostolic teachings about false teachers and moral decay in the end times. The connection to 'the last days' supports both an immediate and future fulfillment.

verses.text: and saying, 'Where is the promise of His coming? For ever since the fathers fell asleep, all things continue as they have from the beginning of creation.'
verses.comment: The skepticism about Christ's return was present even in the early church. The reference to the 'fathers' aligns the Christian faith with Israel's history.

verses.text: For they deliberately overlook this fact: that by the word of God, the heavens existed long ago and the earth was formed out of water and through water,
verses.comment: Peter references the creation account, upholding the teaching that the world was formed by God's word, not by chance. Early Church Fathers also cited this as evidence of God’s continual involvement with His creation.

verses.text: through which the world at that time was destroyed, being flooded with water.
verses.comment: The flood is depicted as real historical judgment. This parallels God's future judgment, showing continuity of His justice throughout salvation history.

verses.text: But by the same word, the present heavens and earth are being reserved for fire, kept for the day of judgment and the destruction of ungodly men.
verses.comment: God's word both created and now sustains the world for eventual judgment, suggesting a sacramental understanding of God’s ongoing action in creation.

verses.text: But do not overlook this one thing, beloved: that with the Lord one day is as a thousand years, and a thousand years as one day.
verses.comment: God’s timeline is not like ours. The patience of the Lord gives space for repentance, tied to the teaching on God's mercy and long-suffering.

verses.text: The Lord is not slow about His promise, as some count slowness, but is patient toward you, not wishing that any should perish but that all should come to repentance.
verses.comment: God’s desire for universal repentance affirms His mercy and calls every person to conversion, reflecting both the justice and mercy of God.

verses.text: But the day of the Lord will come like a thief, and then the heavens will pass away with a roar, and the heavenly bodies will be burned up and dissolved, and the earth and the works done on it will be exposed.
verses.comment: The unexpectedness of the Lord’s return should lead Christians to continual vigilance, repentance, and preparation through a life of holiness (Luke 12:40).

verses.text: Since all these things are thus to be dissolved, what sort of people ought you to be in holy conduct and godliness,
verses.comment: Christian life is marked by holiness in view of the coming transformation of the world. This connects to the call to ongoing sanctification.

verses.text: as you look for and hasten the coming of the day of God, because of which the heavens will be set on fire and dissolved, and the elements will melt with intense heat.
verses.comment: Believers are not just to wait passively but to actively prepare for the Lord’s coming. There is an eschatological urgency and hope presented here.

verses.text: But according to His promise, we are looking for new heavens and a new earth, in which righteousness dwells.
verses.comment: The promise of a new creation is rooted in Old Testament prophecy and fulfilled in Christ. Early Christians interpreted this as a fully restored creation.

verses.text: Therefore, beloved, since you are looking for these things, be diligent to be found by Him in peace, without spot or blemish.
verses.comment: The call to be 'without spot or blemish' points to striving for sanctity and remaining in grace, reminiscent of the Church as Christ’s spotless Bride.

verses.text: And consider the patience of our Lord as salvation, just as our beloved brother Paul also wrote to you according to the wisdom given him.
verses.comment: Reference to Paul's letters as authoritative demonstrates the unity of apostolic teaching and tradition. The message is consistent and divinely inspired.

verses.text: As he does in all his letters when he speaks in them of these matters. There are some things in them that are hard to understand, which the ignorant and unstable twist to their own destruction, as they do the other Scriptures.
verses.comment: Peter acknowledges both the inspiration of Paul's letters and the danger of misinterpretation. The reference to 'the other Scriptures' affirms the early recognition of apostolic writings as Scripture, indicating the value of trusting the Church’s teaching authority.

verses.text: You therefore, beloved, knowing this beforehand, be on your guard so that you are not carried away by the error of the lawless and fall from your own steadfastness.
verses.comment: A warning against false teachers urges believers to remain in the truth received from the apostles, emphasizing the significance of both doctrine and perseverance.

verses.text: But grow in the grace and knowledge of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. To Him be glory both now and forever. Amen.
verses.comment: The Christian life is a journey of growing in grace, pointing to both doctrinal growth and participation in God’s life through faith and the sacraments. Christ’s glory is both present and eternal.
